title: Barclays experiment tests emotional responses to financial words
text:
Barclays is working with researchers at Goldsmiths, University of London, to test emotional responses to financial words.

Participants in the trial were asked to fill in questionnaires about their feelings and complete a 'Stroop test' to assess their reaction times.

This is where coloured words flash up on a screen and you have to hit the button which corresponds to the colour.

Money worries: Barclays is working with researchers at Goldsmiths, University of London, to test emotional responses to financial words

The idea is that the slower your response, the more anxious you feel.

The results revealed that two-thirds of participants felt stressed when faced with financial trigger words, Barclays says.

In the Stroop test, people tended to respond slowest to 'stockbroker', then 'asset manager' and 'investment risk'.

Nearly three-quarters reported an increased heart rate during the test. Men had stronger adverse reactions than women.

Ross Dalzell, of Barclays Smart Investor, says: 'It's clear the industry needs to rethink the way we talk about investing.'
